meanings.def: on the subject of somebody/something; in connection with somebody/something
examples: a book about flowers
Tell me all about it.
What's she so angry about?
There's something strange about him.
There's something about this business that is not quite right.
I don't know what you're on about (= talking about).
There's nothing you can do about it now.
The book is about homeless people in the cities.
The report deals with the issue of homelessness in London.
The writer discusses the problems faced by homeless people.
The article presents an overview of the issues surrounding homelessness.
The novel explores the theme of friendship among homeless people.
The first chapter examines the relationship between homelessness and drug addiction.
The paper considers the question of why so many young people become homeless.

meanings.def: used to describe the purpose or an aspect of something
examples: Movies are all about making money these days.
What was all that about? (= what was the reason for what has just happened?)

meanings.def: busy with something; doing something
examples: Everywhere people were going about their daily business.
And while you’re about it… (= while you’re doing that)

meanings.def: in many directions in a place; here and there
examples: We wandered about the town for an hour or so.
He looked about the room.

meanings.def: in various parts of a place; here and there
examples: The papers were strewn about the room.

meanings.def: next to a place or person; in the area mentioned
examples: She's somewhere about the office.

meanings.def: surrounding somebody/something
examples: She wore a shawl about her shoulders.

meanings.def: used when asking for information about somebody/something
examples: How about Ruth? Have you heard from her?
I'm having fish. What about you?

meanings.def: used to make a suggestion
examples: How about going for a walk?
(especially North American English) How about we go for a walk?
What about a break?

idioms.def: used when asking for information about somebody/something
examples: How about Ruth? Have you heard from her?
I'm having fish. What about you?
How about going for a walk?
(especially North American English) How about we go for a walk?
What about a break?

meanings.def: a little more or less than; a little before or after
examples: It costs about $10.
They waited (for) about an hour.
He arrived (at) about ten.

meanings.def: nearly; very close to
examples: I'm just about ready.
This is about the best we can hope for.

meanings.def: in many directions; here and there
examples: The children were rushing about in the garden.

meanings.def: in no particular order; in various places
examples: Her books were lying about on the floor.

meanings.def: doing nothing in particular
examples: People were standing about in the road.

meanings.def: able to be found in a place
examples: There was nobody about.
There's a lot of flu about.
She’s somewhere about—I saw her a few minutes ago.

meanings.def: facing the opposite direction
examples: He brought the ship about.
The earth goes round/​around the sun.
They live round/​around the corner.
We travelled round/​around India.
She turned round/​around when I came in.
The kids were running around/​round/​about outside.
I’ve been waiting around/​round/​about to see her all day.
We left around/​about 8 o’clock.

meanings.def: almost; very nearly
examples: I've met just about everyone.
‘Did you reach your sales target?’ ‘Just about.’

meanings.def: approximately
examples: She should be arriving just about now.

meanings.def: able to go outside again after an illness
travelling around a place
examples: We've been out and about talking to people all over the country.

meanings.def: used to say that you have finished telling somebody about something and there is nothing to add
examples: ‘Anything else?’ ‘No, that's about it for now.’
I've met just about everyone.
‘Did you reach your sales target?’ ‘Just about.’
She should be arriving just about now.

idioms.def: able to go outside again after an illness
examples: We've been out and about talking to people all over the country.

idioms.idiom: that’s about all | that’s about it
idioms.def: used to say that you have finished telling somebody about something and there is nothing to add
examples: ‘Anything else?’ ‘No, that's about it for now.’

meanings.def: to be close to doing something; to be going to do something very soon
examples: I was just about to ask you the same thing.

meanings.def: to not be willing to do something; to not intend to do something
examples: I've never done any cooking and I'm not about to start now.

idioms.def: to be close to doing something; to be going to do something very soon
examples: I was just about to ask you the same thing.

idioms.idiom: be not about to do something
idioms.def: to not be willing to do something; to not intend to do something
examples: I've never done any cooking and I'm not about to start now.
